title: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Neonatal diaphragmatic defect causing pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress
setup_script: A full-term newborn develops severe respiratory distress immediately after birth. The abdomen appears scaphoid and bowel sounds are heard in the chest. The infant was delivered after an uncomplicated pregnancy. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: “HR 170 bpm, RR 60/min, SpO₂ 80% on blow-by oxygen; the baby is cyanotic.”
“The infant has a barrel-shaped chest, scaphoid abdomen, decreased breath sounds on the left, and heart sounds shifted to the right.”
“Loops of bowel are seen in the left hemithorax with mediastinal shift; the diaphragmatic dome is not visualized.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident immediately intubates and avoids bag–mask ventilation
dynamic_flow.reply: “The airway is secured without gastric insufflation. An NG tube is placed for decompression.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts gentle ventilation with permissive hypercapnia
dynamic_flow.reply: “The infant is oxygenated with improved but still low saturations; barotrauma is avoided.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident obtains arterial blood gas
dynamic_flow.reply: “Results show respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia. Ventilator adjustments may be necessary.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: “An echocardiogram is obtained to assess pulmonary hypertension and structural heart disease.”
“Surgical repair is planned but delayed until stabilization of pulmonary hypertension, typically within the first week of life.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient deteriorates despite maximal ventilatory support
dynamic_flow.reply: “The infant remains hypoxemic. ECMO is considered as a bridge to surgery.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays intubation and uses bag–mask
dynamic_flow.reply: “The stomach distends and the respiratory status worsens with increased cyanosis.”
“The infant requires prolonged ventilatory support, management of pulmonary hypertension, and attention to feeding intolerance.”
“Discussion includes long-term outcomes such as chronic lung disease, gastroesophageal reflux, and potential developmental delays.”

critical_decision_points: Immediate airway management and avoidance of bag–mask ventilation
Diagnosis via chest X-ray and recognition of physical signs
Stabilization of pulmonary hypertension prior to surgical repair
Consideration of ECMO for refractory respiratory failure
Comprehensive parental counseling and long-term follow-up
